dsa_assignment5

Class Graph

  • java.lang.Object
    • dsa_assignment5.Graph

  • public class Graph
extends java.lang.Object
    An Undirected Graph class implemented in an Adjacency List style This is an adjacency list representation of a graph. Nodes are integers starting at 0. The textbooks usually describe an adjacency list as a list (or array), indexed by node numbers, of connection lists. If we did that in Java we would continually end up checking for our node numbers being within range. Further, we normally want a whole object for the node rather than just an integer, so a Map instead of an array is a good choice. The graph is represented by a Map which maps the node number to a LinkedList of Connection objects, which represent the nodes that are directly connected to this node.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Graph

        public Graph()
        It is okay to create an empty graph, as we can add edges to it

      • Graph

        public Graph(int[][] connections)
      throws dsa_assignment5.GraphException
        Create a graph from an array of edges. Each edge is itself an array of 3 integers, the source node, the destination node and the distance between them. Each edge in the input array will be added using addEdge(node1,node2,distance), implying that the reverse of each edge is also added and should NOT be explicitly in the input array.
        Parameters:
        connections - the array of edges to add
        Throws:
        dsa_assignment5.GraphException - if there are not exactly 3 integers in each edge array

      • getConnections

        public int[][] getConnections()
        Get an array of edges in the same form as the array of edges Graph constructor. One important difference is that this returns ALL the individual edges, thus one for the forward and one for the reverse direction of each true edge.
        Returns:
        the array of edges in the graph

      • addEdge

        public void addEdge(int node1,
                    int node2,
                    int distance)
             throws dsa_assignment5.GraphException
        Add an edge to the graph This graph is UNDIRECTED, so any time we add an edge we must add the reverse edge as well.
        Parameters:
        node1 - The source node
        node2 - The destination node
        distance - The distance or weight on the edge
        Throws:
        dsa_assignment5.GraphException - if the distance is negative

      • contractNodeWithTwoEdges

        public void contractNodeWithTwoEdges(int node)
                              throws dsa_assignment5.GraphException
        Contract a node that has exactly two connecting edges

        This is the simplest case of contracting nodes. If node X is connected to node A with distance a and node B with distance b, then this should remove both the X-A and the X-B edge (essentially removing X from the graph), and add a new edge (A-B) with distance a+b

        Note that there may already be a pre-existing edge between A and B. This should not be changed or removed.

        Parameters:
        node - the node to be contracted
        Throws:
        dsa_assignment5.GraphException - if the node to be contracted does not exist in the graph or does not have precisely two edges

      • dijkstra

        public int dijkstra(int node1,
                    int node2)
             throws dsa_assignment5.GraphException
        Apply Dijkstra's algorithm to find the distance between 2 nodes in the graph

        The version of the algorithm to implement is Version 1 from the Theory part handout of the module. Do not try to use Java's PriorityQueue to implement Version 2 as that cannot cope with the priority of an object in the queue changing while the object is in the queue.

        Rather than using the arrays as described in the handout, I recommend you use

        • Integer.MAX_VALUE for infinity
        • A Map<Integer, Integer> for the D array in the notes, to record the minimum distance found so far from the start node for each node in the graph
        • A Set<Integer> called nonTight of nodes to represent the set of nodes for which you have not yet found tight distance values for. This is equivalent to the tight array of booleans in the handout but it is much easier and more efficient to iterate over the nonTight set than iterate over the nodes whose boolean values in the tight array are true

        There is no need to have a pred variable as there is no need to calculate or return the route of the shortest path

        Parameters:
        node1 - the start node in the pair between which the distance is to be found
        node2 - the final node in the pair between which the distance is to be found
        Returns:
        the distance between the pair of nodes
        Throws:
        dsa_assignment5.GraphException - if either of the nodes are not in the graph or there is no path between them
